Graphical abstract By a facile hydrothermal method, an ideal CZA2 support in which the homogeneous CeO2-ZrO2(CZ) solid solution was stabilized by Al2O3 in nanorods and nanofibers shapes has been fabricated successfully. The prepared CZA2 exhibits large pore volume (0.66 mL/g), wider average pore radius (25.3 nm), superior reducibility and more surface oxygen vacancies. Consequently, its supported Pd/CZA2 could keep a better three-way catalytic activity even being thermally aged. In this work, a highly active CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3(CZA2) support material was successfully fabricated and the activity of its supported Pd-only three-way was also characterized. Pd/CZA2-a (aged catalyst) could maintain a superior activity and thermal stability, the T50 of CO, NO, C3H8 and C3H6 over which decrease by 34 °C, 32 °C, 29 °C and 28 °C than that over Pd/CZA1-a (reference catalyst). As characterized, the superior activity of Pd/CZA2 associates closely with the highly porous structure and advanced reducibility of the support material. By N2 adsorption–desorption analysis, TEM and SEM analysis, CZA2 displays large pore volume (0.66 mL/g) and wider pore radius (25.3 nm), which benefits the diffusion of reactant in emissions with high space velocity. And such larger pore volume and pore radius of CZA2, comparing to CZA1 (0.39 mL/g in pore volume, 8.6 nm in pore radius) with amorphous Al2O3 and those reported CZA materials, is associated with the morphology (nanorods and nanofibers) and stacking of primary particles. In addition, results of XRD and XPS manifest that the superior reducibility of CZA2 is associated with the homogenous CZ structure and the resulting increased surface oxygen vacancies. Then these vacancies maintain the smaller PdO crystal size and higher fraction of Pd2+ in the thermal treatment due to the increased metal-support interaction between CZA2 and Pd species. As a result, Pd/CZA2-a could keep a better three-way catalytic activity. Keywords Nanostructured Al2O3 Highly porous structure Homogeneous CZ solid solution Pd-only three-way catalyst Introduction Emission from automotive vehicle is becoming a major source of air pollution and has attracted worldwide attention. Three-way catalysts (TWCs) aiming at purifying CO, HC and NOx simultaneously in exhaust is one of the highly efficient methods in emission control [1]. CeO2-ZrO2(CZ) mixed oxides with superior oxygen storage have been considered as an indispensable support in TWCs for its critical role in compensating the air/fuel ratio fluctuations in the exhaust stream [2]. However, CZ is susceptible to sinter at higher temperature, which usually leads to the severe reduction of the oxygen storage capacity [3]. Introducing Al2O3 into CZ system could remarkably promote the thermal stability and the specific surface area of CZ material due to the “diffusion barrier effect” [4,5]. However, the CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3(CZA) support materials most reported usually display narrow pore distribution, small pore size and inferior reducibility [6,7]. On the one hand, as identified by extensive references, the support with larger pores has little diffusional restrictions in heterogeneous reactions [8,9]. On the other hand, the CZA with superior reducibility is beneficial to prevent the thermal sintering of Pd species in high temperature due to the strong metal-support interaction [10–12]. Considering the high space velocity and high temperature of the emission environment, the supports with highly porous structures and superior redox property are highly demanded. By now, great progress has been made in the designing of pore structure. By optimizing the preparation process [13], adding surfactants/template, like lauric acid [14], N235 [15], PMMA [16,17] et al., the CZ-based support material with larger pore volume and wide pore size distribution could be achieved. However, complex process, expensive and harmful organic reagents are needed in most cases, which is disadvantageous to their practical applications in terms of economic and environmental sustainability. As generally accepted, pore structure of the nanomaterial is dependent upon the morphology and stacking of primary particles [18]. Recently, the designing and synthesis of Al2O3-based materials with desired morphology has stimulated great interests. And alumina nanofibers [19–21], nanowires [22], nanorods [23,24], and nanoplates [25–28] have also been fabricated successfully by many researches. Among them, special interests have been paid to the Al2O3 in nanorods and nanofibers shapes, since these nanostructured Al2O3-based materials usually have large surface area, large pore volume and wider pore size distribution. Meanwhile, a facile hydrothermal method has also been put forward to fabricate these nanostructured Al2O3 nanomaterial by regulating the pH, temperature and precursor concentration in the preparation process without the use of surfactants and templates [29,30]. In addition, some works have also disclosed the advantages of nanostructured alumina as supports in dispersing active component in heterogeneous catalysts [20,31]. Additionally, massive literatures have also disclosed the multiple positive roles of hydrothermal treatment in preparing desired CZ-based materials. By hydrothermal digesting the freshly precipitated cerium-zirconium hydroxides, Raju et al. synthesized a CZ solid solution with larger surface area, which leads to more gas-surface interaction and thus facilitates the removal of oxygen species [32]. In our previous work, we have also concluded that the incorporation of rear earth metals into the CeO2 lattice could be accelerated by hydrothermal treatment, and thus the CZ solid solution with more defective structure and superior reducibility has been prepared [33]. Motivated by these researches, it is reasonable to infer that a desired CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3 with large porosity and reducibility could be achieved by a facile hydrothermal treatment. Then, in this article, the effects of hydrothermal treatment on the properties of the resulting CZA material will be systematically investigated, and the three-way catalytic activity of Pd loaded on the CZA materials as well as the relationship between the reducibility of CZA and the activity of its supported Pd-only three-way catalyst will be discussed. Experimental Materials preparation The composition of all the CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3(CZA) materials is identical, in which CeO2-ZrO2/Al2O3 = 1/1 (wt%/wt%) and Ce/Zr = 1/1(mol/mol). Specifically, CZA1 was prepared by the conventional sequential precipitation method. Firstly, the Ce(NO3)3•6H2O was dissolved by distilled water, then a certain amount of H2O2 was introduced into the solution to oxidize Ce3+ to Ce4+(nH2O2/nCe 3+ = 0.23). After dissolving ZrOCO3 with concentrated nitric acid (16 mol/L), a mixed salt solution of CZ was prepared. Meanwhile, the certain amount of Al(NO3)3•9H2O was dissolved by distilled water to obtain the corresponding solution. Then the Al3+ was precipitated firstly by a buffer solution composed by ammonia solution (3 mol/L) and (NH4)2CO3 solution (3 mol/L) under vigorous stirring. After that, the CZ mixed salt solution was precipitated by the same buffer solution in the same reactor. During the whole process, the pH was kept at around 8.8-9.0. After that, the precipitates were aged at 90 °C for 6 h. Then the precipitates were filtered and dried at 80 °C for 24 h to get the dried CZA1-d. Next, the CZA1-d was calcined in static air at 600 °C for 3 h to get the fresh material marked as CZA1-f. Then the CZA1-f was further thermally aged in static air at 1000 °C for 4 h to get the aged samples CZA1-a. The CZA2 was synthesized in the similar way with that of CZA1, except that the precipitated precursor was aged at 90 °C for 18 h firstly before the following procedure. Catalyst preparation The aged CZA materials were used as the support to impregnate 1.0 wt% Pd with Pd(NO3)2 aqueous solution as precursor. Then the powders were dried at 120 °C for 12 h and treated at 550 °C for 3 h to get the fresh catalyst (Pd/CZA-f). After that, the powders were mixed with de-ionized water to produce slurries to be coated to cylindrical cordierite monoliths (Corning, USA, 400 cells/in.2 and 2.5 cm3) with the desirable loading of 140 g L−1. Afterwards, the catalysts were calcined at 900 °C for 3 h to get the aged catalysts (Pd/CZA-a). Catalytic activity measurements The three-way catalytic activity was evaluated in a fixed-bed reactor, in which the simulated exhaust gases includes O2 (4335 ppm), NO (1300 ppm), CO (5000 ppm), H2 (1700 ppm), C3H8 (120 ppm), C3H6 (230 ppm), CO2 (10.5%), H2O (10.0%) and N2 (as balance gas). Before the measurement, the catalysts were pretreated at 550 °C for 1 h under the simulated exhaust. Afterwards, the catalyst was cooled down to the desired temperature, and then the conversions of CO, NO, C3H8 and C3H6 with temperature were monitored on-line by a Thermo Scientific AntarisIGS Gas Analyzer. In all the measurements, the gas hourly space velocity was kept at 50,000 h−1. Characterization technology The microscopic morphology of the materials was characterized by Transmission electron microscope (TEM) and Scanning electron microscope (SEM). The TEM was carried out on the FEI titan themis 200 transmission electron microscope (FEI, USA), which equipped with Bruker super-X energy-dispersive spectrometer (EDS). The SEM was performed on the FEI inspect F50 (FEI, USA) with 5.0 kV accelerating voltage. The specific surface areas, cumulative pore volume and BJH pore size distribution of these CZA materials were characterized at −196 °C by the Quantachrome automated surface area & pore size analyzer (Autosorb SI). And before the measurement, these CZA materials would be degassed at 300 °C for 1 h to clean the surface. In addition, the Small-angle XRD data were also collected to further investigate the order of the pore structures. In detail, the Small-angle XRD patterns were characterized on Xeuss 2.0 X-ray diffractometer, and the range of scan was 2θ = 1°–10°. The redox properties of these CZA materials were characterized by Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) as well as Oxygen storage capacity (OSC). In detail, the TPR experiment was performed on the TP-5076 temperature-programmed adsorption instrument. Prior to the H2-TPR measurement, 100 mg sample was pretreated in N2 flow (25 mL/min) at 450 °C for 1 h to eliminate the surface contaminants. After being cooled to room temperature, the 5% H2/N2(reducing gas) was switched into the system. Then the reduction was recorded by raising the temperature to 900 °C at a constant rate of 10 °C/min. The OSC was characterized by a pulse method on the self-made instrument. In detail, after being pre-reduced at 450 °C for 40 min in the flow of H2, the O2 pulse experiment was injected until the height of adsorption peak keeps steady. The phase structures of these CZA materials were characterized by the Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), which were performed on the Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan). The patterns were recorded in the range of 10°< 2θ< 90°. And the measurement was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA and with 0.02° step size using nickel-filtered Cu-Ka radiation. The surface property of the CZA material and its supported Pd-only three way catalysts was characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on XSAM-800 electron spectrometer (Kratos, Britain). The profiles were recorded at 13 kV and 20 mA using Mg Ka (1253.6 eV) as the X-ray source. In order to calibrate the surface charging effect, all the profiles were calibrated using the binding energy of C 1s (284.6 eV) as internal standard. Results and discussion TEM and SEM results In order to investigate the morphology of the CZA materials, the TEM and SEM were carried out and the results are displayed in Fig. 1 and Fig. 2 . Obviously, TEM and SEM profiles confirm the morphological differences between CZA1 and CZA2. In Fig. 1(a) and Fig. 2(a), agglomerated nanoparticles with irregular shapes are observed in CZA1-f. In contrast, Fig. 1(b) manifests that hybrids nanoparticles with fibers, nanorods and hexagonal shapes have been successfully fabricated in CZA2-f. Similar differences are also characterized in the SEM profiles in Fig. 2(b–d) that CZA2-a could keep sparsely agglomerated morphology even being thermally aged. As presented in Fig. 1(g), the nanoparticles with fibers and nanorod shapes are referred to γ-Al2O3 with the interplanar spacing of 0.20 nm for (200) crystal plane (PDF-75-0921). And the hexagonal nanoparticles in Fig. 1(f) can unambiguously be attributed to the cubic CZ solid solution with 0.28 nm and 0.31 nm for the interplanar spacing of (200) and (111) crystal plane, respectively (PDF-54-0017). That is to say, the nanostructured Al2O3 supported CeO2-ZrO2 composite material has been successfully achieved by this facile hydrothermal method. In addition, special attention should be paid to the intracrystalline small porosity presented in the insert nanorod of Fig. 1(c). Such intracrystalline porosity has also been observed in NH4Al(OH)2CO3-derived Al2O3 by Laffiche and Hu et al., who have associated it with the decomposition of NH4Al(OH)2CO3(AACH) [34,35]. As reported, NH4 + and CO3 2− are located between the Al-O octahedrons chains in AACH by weak bonds. During the decomposition of AACH, these weak bonds contacted with NH4 + and CO3 2- would break along with the emission of NH3, CO2 and H2O, then producing these disordered intracrystalline pores [36]. However, these disordered intracrystalline small pores have disappeared when these Al2O3 nanorods are submitted to high temperature treatment (as presented in Fig. 1e). N2 adsorption–desorption analysis As generally accepted, the textural property of the nanomaterials is associated with accumulation mode of the primary particles. Then in Fig. 3 and Table 1 , the textural property is shown. In Fig. 3(a–b), all CZA show IV-type isothermal with hysteresis loops characteristic of capillary condensation in mesopores. The isotherms of CZA1-f and CZA1-a tend to reach a plateau above a certain pressure, meanwhile, the relative pressure at which the plateau attained increase from P/P0 = 0.90 for CZA1-f to 0.94 for CZA1-a, indicating the increase of mean pore size due to the collapse and sintering of small pores during the thermal treatments [19]. By comparison, the plateau for the CZA-2 is no longer detected, on contrary, the isotherms continuously increase until saturation (P/P0 = 1). According to IUPAC recommendations, the hysteresis loops in CZA1 could be classified as H2 type, which refers to the tubular mesopores. However, the hysteresis loop shape for CZA2 is grouped within H3 and H4 type, indicating its larger pores than CZA1 [37]. It also indicates the disparity of the accumulation mode for the nanoparticles between CZA1 and CZA2, the results of which are great accordance with TEM and SEM characterization. In addition, Fig. 3 also depicts the BJH pore size distribution and the corresponding fraction of pore with different size. Obviously, CZA1-f displays a unimodal pore size distribution with pore below 10 nm (the insert of Fig. 3a). Differently, CZA2-f exhibits a bimodal pore size distribution, which associates with intracrystalline porosity and the accumulation of crystal with different shapes (the insert of Fig. 3b). In detail, the first peak around the limit between micro- and mesoporosity is associated with the intracrystalline small porosity as supported by the TEM results (Section 4.1), resulting from the decomposition of AACH. Another peak is centered at 15 nm, and the results are consistent with the literatures that nanostructures Al2O3 usually has larger pore size [8,20]. In addition, it should also be noted that the porosity resulting from crystal accumulation is predominant since the majority pores in CZA2-f are within 10–20 nm as presented in Fig. 3(c). After being thermally treated, the smaller pores below 10 nm for CZA2-f disappear and the fraction of pores in the range of 10–20 nm increases (Fig. 3d). And the results are also in great accordance with TEM results that those intracrystalline porosity have disappeared after being thermally treated (Fig.1d). Significantly, the majority of pores in CZA1-a is kept below 10 nm although larger pores have also been detected (Fig. 3d). Meanwhile, as summarized in Table 1, both the CZA materials display similar specific surface area (> 200 m2/g for fresh materials and ca.70 m2/g for aged materials), CZA2 exhibits nearly twice larger pore volume (0.66 mL/g) and three times larger average pore radius (25.3 nm) than CZA1(0.39 mL/g, 8.55 nm). Meanwhile, the pore volume and average pore radius of CZA2-a is even larger than the most reported results (the textural properties of reported CZA are summarized in Table 1). As reported, supports with larger pores exhibit limited diffusional restrictions thus facilitate the access of reactants to the active sites. Then it could infer that CZA2 is more suitable for the TWCs due to its high velocity. Small-angle XRD results In order to further investigate the pore structures of the CZA materials, the small-angle XRD result was characterized and the results are presented in Fig. 4 . As illustrated, a well-defined reflection centered at 2θ = 0.59° is observed in the fresh CZA materials. Considering no highly ordered pore structures have been detected in the TEM profiles, the broad peak of CZA1-f observed in Fig. 4 may associate with its wormhole-like pores [43], while the sharp peak of CZA2 may associate with its uniform morphology of its building block as literatures reported [44]. And special attention should be paid that the characteristic peak for CZA1-a disappears, indicating a poor stability of its pore structures. H2-TPR and OSC results Except the textural property, redox property of the CZA material is one of the crucial factors for the application of CZA support material in three-way catalytic reaction. In order to investigate the redox properties of the CZA materials, the H2-TPR and OSC characterizations were carried out and the results are displayed in Fig. 5 . As proposed by previous works, the broad H2 consumption peak in 300–700 °C is attributed to the co-reduction of surface and subsurface oxygen species of CZ solid solution, and the reduction peak above 800 °C is associated with the reduction of bulk oxygen, which is intrinsic to CeO2 [45]. As shown in Fig. 5(a), the peak temperature ascribed to surface and sub-surface oxygen reduction decreases from 600 °C for CZA1-f to 580 °C for CZA2-f, inferring the faster mobility of oxygen species in CZA2-f. Meanwhile, CZA2-f also exhibits a minor bulk oxygen reduction peak at 871 °C, indicating that a more homogeneous CZ solid solution has formed in CZA2-f. After being thermal aged, the reduction peak above 800 °C disappeared due to the formation of more homogeneous CZ solid solution [45]. Meanwhile, more obvious differences could be observed in CZA-a material in Fig. 5(b). In detail, CZA2-a could keep the lower reduction temperature of surface/subsurface oxygen species, which decreases by 82 °C than CZA1-a. In addition, the integrated reduction peak area was also calculated and the results are displayed in Fig. 5(c). Clearly, CZA2-a exhibits a larger H2 consumption in the process of surface oxygen reduction (< 550 °C), manifesting their better mobility of surface oxygen species. Besides, the larger reduction peak area (Fig. 5c) and higher OSC value (Fig. 5d) also demonstrate its high Ce efficiency (65%) and better redox property of CZA2-a than CZA1-a. As proposed by previous works, the reduction property of CZ-based material correlates closely with the surface area and the homogeneity of Zr distribution in CeO2 framework [13,46]. As discussed in Section 4.3, although CZA2-a exhibits a much higher pore volume and average pore radius, the surface area of the aged CZA materials are close to each other. Consequently, it could infer that the superior redox of CZA2-a is mainly associated with the homogeneous structure of CZ solid solution. XRD results Given the fact that the composition and surface area of the CZA material are almost identical, the difference in the reducibility is likely associated with their homogeneous structure of CZ. Meanwhile, in order to give deep insight into the effects of hydrothermal treatment on the phase structure, the XRD characterization was carried out and the results are summarized in Fig. 6 , Fig. 8 and Fig. 9 . As observed in Fig. 6(a), CZA1-d and CZA2-d show similar main diffraction peaks ascribed to cubic Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 (PDF 28-0271) and NH4Al(OH)2CO3•H2O (PDF 29-0106). That is to say, the excess Zr species are in amorphous phase since the nCe/nZr = 1/1 mol/mol in the composition. In addition, obvious differences could be found in the amplifying profiles displayed in Fig. 6(b–c). In Fig, 6(b), a more diffuse peak associated with the (111) crystal plane of Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 solid solution is observed in CZA2-d. It indicates that the Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 nanoparticles with smaller crystal size in CZA2-d are highly dispersed on the surface of NH4Al(OH)2CO3•H2O (the TEM profile is presented in Fig. 7). In addition, in Fig. 6 (b), the 2θ value of the peak has increased form 28.58° for CZA1-d to 28.71° for CZA2-d, indicating a shrinkage of CZ lattice according to Vegard’s rule. It could be referred that more Zr4+ ions have inserted into the CeO2 lattice during the hydrothermal treatment due to its smaller radius than Ce3+/Ce4+. Besides, as presented in Fig. 6(c), the sharper peak indicates that the hydrothermal treatment has promoted the growth of NH4Al(OH)2CO3•H2O, thus a much larger crystal size in CZA2-d (11.1 nm) than in CZA1-d (7.2 nm) is characterized. More importantly, a great difference has been detected in Fig. 6(d) that the peak ascribed to AlO(OH) is only observed in CZA2-d. That is to say, Al3+ has hydrolyzed in the process of hydrothermal treatment in open system due to the markedly decreased concentration of NH4 +, CO3 2− and OH- [47,48]. Then the hybrids shapes of nanorods and nanofibers have been observed in Fig. 1 and Fig. 7. As manifested by HRTEM discussed in Section 3.1, NH4Al(OH)2CO3•H2O-derived Al2O3 exhibits a nanorod shape, then we attributed that the Al2O3 nanofibers come from the transformation of the AlO(OH). As reported, boehmite has a fully hydroxylated surface and these surface hydroxyl groups would be lost by thermal treatment followed by incorporation of terminal oxygen ions without altering the morphology [26]. Besides, as shown in Fig. 8, phase transformation has occurred during thermal treatment since CZA-f materials feature the similar characteristic peaks of cubic Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 and γ-Al2O3. Meanwhile, obvious differences could be detected in the amplifying patterns presented in Fig. 8(b–c). As identified, the diffraction peak presented in Fig. 8(b) is associated with the (101) crystal plane of cubic CZ. With respect to CZA1-f, the peak of CZA2-f presented in Fig. 8(b) shifts to higher angle, indicating the CZ lattice contraction. As disclosed, Al2O3 could not be incorporated into the CZ framework to form CZA solid solution [4,5], then it could infer that more homogeneous CZ structure have been achieved within CZA2-f due to the smaller ionic radius of Zr4+(0.88 Å) than that of Ce4+(0.97 Å). As extensive literatures reported, the incorporation of Zr cations into CeO2 lattice could promote the formation of defect sites by lattice distortion and charge-compensating [49]. And these oxygen defects would make more mobile lattice oxygen available during redox processes [2,20,21,24]. Consequently, CZA2-f could exhibit a superior redox property than CZA1-f. However, as exhibited in Fig. 8(c), much sharper diffraction peak referring to γ-Al2O3 in CZA2-f has also been observed. As shown in Table 2 , CZA2-f exhibits a larger γ-Al2O3 crystal size of 5.7 nm than CZA1-f (4.8 nm), which is associated with the well-crystallized NH4Al(OH)2CO3•H2O precursor as manifested above. On contrary, the CZ crystal size in the fresh CZA materials are almost identical at 4.5 nm. However, it indicates a fast growth rate of CZ crystal in CZA2-f since a smaller crystal size of CZ in CZA2-d is manifested by the diffuse diffraction in Fig. 6(b). After being thermally aged at 1000 °C for 4 h, significant differences have also been detected in Fig. 9. As shown in Fig. 9(b), an obvious asymmetric peak associated with new phase of Zr0.82Ce0.18O2 has been observed in CZA1-a. It indicates that phase separation has occurred in CZA1 during thermal treatment, which refers to its poor phase stability of CZ solid solution. More importantly, Fig. 10 illustrates the shift of CZ peak during the thermal treatment. Obviously, a gradual upshift of the peak is observed for both CZA1 and CZA2 when the treat temperature increased from 80 °C to 900 °C, indicating that Zr ions would be incorporated into CeO2 lattice in the drive of temperature. However, when the materials are thermal treated at 1000 °C, a decrease of the 2θ value is also found in CZA1-a while that of CZA2-a almost keeps unchanged. And it also elaborates the phase separation of CZA1-a, which is caused by Zr4+ migrating from CeO2 lattice. On contrary, as displayed in Fig. 9 (c), a more obvious peak of θ-Al2O3 is observed in CZA2-a than CZA1-a due to the sever thermal sintering. As early as 2008, Morikawa et al. has disclosed that the “diffusion barrier” effects in CZA system could inhibit the crystal growth and phase transformation of CZ and Al2O3 [50]. However, afterward, Lan et al. further put forward that the strong interaction between ZrO2 and Al2O3 in CZA would disrupt the homogeneous structure of CZ since some Ce-rich and Zr-rich domain are detected [51]. Then combing with the results discussed above, it could be inferred that: (i) the Ce, Zr and Al in CZA1 have strong interaction, thus a smaller CZ and Al2O3 crystal size but a heterogeneous CZ structure are observed. (ii) The hydrothermal treatment benefits the crystallization of Al-intermediates and the incorporation of Zr cation into CeO2 lattice in CZA2; Meanwhile, the NH4Al(OH)2CO3•H2O with high crystallinity interacts rather weakly with ZrO2, then more Zr4+ could be incorporated into CeO2 lattice to form a more homogeneous CZ structure in the thermal treatment. And the diagram of the phase transformation of CZA with temperature is presented in Fig. 11 . TEM-EDS results As presented in Fig. 12 , the 2θ of the main diffraction peak ascribed to cubic CZ reaches to the maximum for both CZA1 and CZA2 when treated at 900 °C, which is closer to the theoretical value of pure CZ (2θ = 29.34°, PDF70-4048). It indicates that homogeneous CZ solid solution has formed when thermal treated at 900 °C, the results of which are accordance with that reported in literature [51]. Then in order to investigate the microscopic composition of the CZ solid solution, the TEM-EDS was performed and the results are presented in Fig. 12. Obviously, two CZ crystal size are observed at the position range of 2.5–20 nm and 30.0–47.5 nm, and the other regions are in Al-rich. More importantly, the nanoscale composition of CZ is somewhat heterogeneous as Mamontov et al. also reported [52]. And the Ce/Zr ratio in the center of CZ crystal is higher than those in the edges, meanwhile, the Ce/Zr ratios in the edges are closer to 1. Considering the phase transformation of CZ from Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 in dried form to Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 after thermal treatment, it could be concluded that the crystallization process of CZ is initiated via the nucleation of ceria-rich nanodomains, then the migration of Zr species into CeO2 lattice in the drive of temperature. In addition, a relatively homogeneous structure has formed in the CZ edges (or the surface/subsurface), then obvious surface and bulk reduction peaks have been characterized in the TPR profiles (Fig. 5b). The three-way catalytic activity In order to further investigate the effects of hydrothermal treatment, the Pd species are loaded on the CZA materials and the results of the three-way catalytic activity are presented in Fig. 13 . Fig. 13 depicts the conversion profiles of CO, NO, C3H8 and C3H6 over the fresh and aged Pd/CZA catalysts. Therein, only slight differences could be found in the fresh catalysts among the catalytic performance. And it may infer that the oxidation state and dispersion of the Pd species in the fresh catalysts are similar. And as expected, the catalytic reactions occurred at comparatively higher temperatures over the aged catalysts due to the thermal aging. However, obvious difference can be found among the conversions between the aged Pd/CZA catalysts. In detail, the T50(50% conversion) of CO, NO, C3H8 and C3H6 over Pd/CZA2-a is 34 °C, 32 °C, 29 °C and 28 °C, respectively, lower than that over Pd/CZA1-a. Meanwhile, special attention should be paid to the ΔT50 between the fresh and aged catalysts in Pd/CZA2- is much lower than in Pd/CZA1. Then it could be concluded that the Pd/CZA catalyst exhibits a superior activity as well as an enhanced thermal stability. Discussion on the TWC activity Generally, the three-way catalytic activity of the catalysts corelates closely with the dispersion and oxidation states of Pd species. And in order to explain the underlying reasons for the differences of three-way catalytic activity between the two catalysts, the XRD and XPS experiments of the catalysts were further carried out and the results are displayed below. XRD results of the Pd-only catalysts In order to investigate the Pd crystal size in the catalysts, the XRD profiles of the catalysts are collected in Fig. S1. By comparing the amplifying profiles between the catalysts and pure supports, an obvious diffraction peak at 2θ = 41.93° in the aged Pd/CZA catalysts could be detected, which is associated with the (110) crystal plane of PdO (PDF 05-0515). However, the characteristic peak referring to PdO is absent in the fresh catalysts, which indicates that the Pd species in fresh catalysts are highly dispersed on the surface of CZA-a supports. In addition, the crystal size of PdO in the aged catalysts was calculated based on Scherrer equation, and the value for Pd/CZA1-a and Pd/CZA2-a is 17.0 nm and 13.6 nm, respectively. Summarizing the similar surface area between CZA1-a and CZA2-a, it could infer that there exists a stronger interaction between CZA2-a and supported Pd species, then resulting a better thermal stability in terms of smaller Pd crystal size in Pd/CZA2-a. XPS results of the CZA support and Pd/CZA catalysts In order to corelate the surface chemical species with the redox property of CZA and the three-way catalytic activity, the XPS was carried out and the results are summarized in Fig. 14–16 and Table 3 . The Ce 3d spectra, shown in Fig. 14, has been fitted into eight peaks associated with four different spin-orbit doublets. And the O 1s shown in spectra in Fig. 14 could be deconvoluted into Oα, Oβ and Oγ, which refers to O2− in CeO2 lattice, O2− ions in the oxygen-deficient regions within the matrix of CeO2 and the surface-chemisorbed oxygen species, respectively [53]. As shown in Table 3, CZA2-a has the higher Ce3+ ratio than CZA1-a. Since the formation of Ce3+ is associated with the oxygen vacancies, then the concentration of oxygen vacancies follows the order: CZA2-a (51.69%)> CZA1-a (47.48%). As generally recognized, the reduction of CZ starts at the surface through successive H2 dissociation and the surface oxygen vacancies benefit the migration of bulk oxygen to the surface [54]. Then CZA2-a could exhibit a much superior redox property than CZA1-a as discussed in Section 3.4. Besides, special attention should be paid that CZA2-a (1.31) also displays a higher Ce/Zr ratio than CZA1-a (0.73) as presented in Table 3, the similar conclusion has also been reported in our previous work that the hydrothermal treatment benefits the formation of Ce-rich surface [33]. According to the literatures, the Ce-containing component could promote the dispersion of Pd species due to their strong interaction [11,12]. Then in order to further investigate the dispersion and chemical states of Pd species, the XPS of the catalysts were carried out and the results are displayed in Fig. 16 and Table 3. As presented in Fig. 16, the Pd 3d XPS spectra could be deconvoluted into two peaks associated with Pd2+ and Pd0. As presented in Table 3, Pd/CZA2-f catalyst exhibits a higher ratio of Pd2+ than Pd/CZA1-f although the almost identical surface Pd content in the two catalysts is observed. During aging process, sintering and decomposition of the Pd species take place, which consequently results in the lowered surface concentration of Pd and Pd2+ ratio. At the same time, more obvious differences could be characterized between the two catalysts in Table 3. In detail, the Pd2+ fraction as well as surface Pd content follows the order of Pd/CZA2-a (57.52%, 0.18%) > Pd/CZA1-a (39.90%, 0.12%), which means the presence of more active sites for three-way catalytic reaction. More importantly, special attention should be paid to the decreased ratio of Ce/Zr, Ce3+ as well as Oβ when Pd species are loaded on the CZA materials. It infers that Pd species may preferentially interact with the surface defects sites by forming Pd-O-Ce bonds as massive literatures reported [33,55]. Then considering the fact that CZA2-a exhibits a superior reducibility (Section 3.1) but a similar surface area (Section 3.3) than CZA1-a supports, it could attribute the more PdO species in Pd/CZA2 to the stronger metal-support interaction between CZA2-a and Pd species. Then the interactions benefit to stabilize Pd species in oxidized state due to the easier electron transfer form Pd to CZ in the Pd-(Ce, Zr)Ox interface [11,12]. Discussion on the relationship between hydrothermal treatment of CZA support with the activity of Pd-only three-way catalyst By summarizing the analysis presented above, the relationship between the hydrothermal treatment of CZA and the activity of its supported Pd-only three-way catalyst could be depicted in Fig. 17 . Then the conclusions could be drawn as follows: (i) The hydrothermal treatment promotes the formation of the relative homogeneous CZ solid solution, then increased Ce3+and Oβ ratio is observed in CZA2-a; (ii) Due to the formation of nanostructured Al2O3 by hydrothermal treatment, the CZA2 exhibits the much higher pore volume; (iii) The hydrothermal treatment modifies the surface property of CZA, then the resulted higher Ce/Zr ratio is detected in CZA2; (iv) The order of Pd dispersion and Pd2+ fraction in the aged catalysts is consistent with the sequence of surface defects (Ce3+and Oβ), Ce/Zr ratio and pore volume of the support. Consequently, it could infer that the CZA material with abundant surface defects and reducibility is beneficial to stabilize the Pd species in the thermal treatment in oxidation state with smaller crystal size. As a result, more active sites with oxidized PdO species for the three-way catalytic reaction is maintained in Pd/CZA2-a, which is beneficial for HC and CO oxidation [56]. In addition, the abundant oxygen defects in Pd-CZ interface for Pd/CZA2-a is also favorable to the dissociation and conversion of NO [57]. Therefore, the Pd/CZA2-a could display a much higher three-way catalytic activity since the T50 for CO, NO, C3H8 and C3H6 over Pd/CZA2-a is 34 °C, 32 °C, 29 °C and 28 °C lower than that over Pd/CZA1-a. Conclusions In this work, a CZA material with higher pore volume, wider pore size distribution and superior reducibility was fabricated by co-precipitation method with a facile hydrothermal treatment. And the results manifest that: (i) the hydrothermal treatment is beneficial to the formation of nanostructured Al2O3 with fiber and nanorod shapes, which contributes to the highly porosity structure; (ii) the hydrothermal treatment remarkably improves the homogeneity of CZ solid solution, resulting in the formation of more surface vacancies. Meanwhile, a Ce-rich surface has also formed by hydrothermal treatment; (iii) the CZA support with superior reducibility and more surface vacancies could stabilize the Pd species in oxidization state with smaller crystal size, then improve the three-way catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: In this work, a highly active CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3(CZA2) support material was successfully fabricated and the activity of its supported Pd-only three-way was also characterized. Pd/CZA2-a (aged catalyst) could maintain a superior activity and thermal stability, the T50 of CO, NO, C3H8 and C3H6 over which decrease by 34 °C, 32 °C, 29 °C and 28 °C than that over Pd/CZA1-a (reference catalyst). As characterized, the superior activity of Pd/CZA2 associates closely with the highly porous structure and advanced reducibility of the support material. By N2 adsorption–desorption analysis, TEM and SEM analysis, CZA2 displays large pore volume (0.66 mL/g) and wider pore radius (25.3 nm), which benefits the diffusion of reactant in emissions with high space velocity. And such larger pore volume and pore radius of CZA2, comparing to CZA1 (0.39 mL/g in pore volume, 8.6 nm in pore radius) with amorphous Al2O3 and those reported CZA materials, is associated with the morphology (nanorods and nanofibers) and stacking of primary particles. In addition, results of XRD and XPS manifest that the superior reducibility of CZA2 is associated with the homogenous CZ structure and the resulting increased surface oxygen vacancies. Then these vacancies maintain the smaller PdO crystal size and higher fraction of Pd2+ in the thermal treatment due to the increased metal-support interaction between CZA2 and Pd species. As a result, Pd/CZA2-a could keep a better three-way catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Designed synthesis of nanostructured Al2O3 stabilized homogeneous CeO2-ZrO2 solid solution as highly active support for Pd-only three-way catalyst
